Easily could've been an iconic and memorable CS game had it not been poorly lumped in with Source's launch time. I really like the art direction and unique little quirks in this game, it's like a more polished and characterised 1.6 but sadly due to its shafted release window it seems it'll always be glossed over. 

Kind of telling when 1.6 and CZ have similar designs and yet CZ is just utterly dead. If you have some friends, get them into it you'll love it. But had it not been dead, this'd definitely be a mainstay for me.

It is the same game as Counter-Strike 1.6, but it is a lot more stable, in addition to having the same arcade mode known as "multiplayer on lan" it has a very fun campaign mode. In Windows 10, Counter-Strike 1.6 (Steam, original) constantly crashed and I had to use old executables from third-party developers to install the bots, in Counter-Strike Condition Zero everything is ready, you can choose between the map in Condition Zero version and 1.6 original. I like playing for Proton through Manjaro Linux because the API fixes anti-aliasing, texture filtering and implemeting an new modern font.

Hostages are much more alive and smart, they take command from afar, show submission to terrorists, panic in moments of combat and express relief after rescue, they crouch and go through pipes following the rescuer, they make the game more alive.

The game is very worthwhile, if you just want to have fun with the bots through the classic maps without stressing about fixing the bugs of Counter-Strike 1.6, consider buying this game.
